turns.content:
Example #1
Focus Area: Health Science Futures
Title: Custom Body Parts In-vivo
Proposed transformation:
Minimally invasive 3D printing in patients of functional tissues and organs on
demand.
How is it done today, and what are the limits of current practice:
3D bio-constructs can be printed, cultured ex-vivo, and successfully
transplanted.
What is new, and why do you think it will be successful and transformational:
Printing tissues (and possibly organs) on demand in-vivo enables the just-intime mass customization of body parts on demand.
Evidence Citation:
Adib, A Asghari, et al. “Direct-Write 3D Printing and Characterization of a
Gelma-Based Biomaterial for Intracorporeal Tissue
Engineering.” Biofabrication, vol. 12, no. 4, 2020, p. 045006.,
https://doi.org/10.1088/1758-5090/ab97a1.
Evidence Summary:
Demonstrated robotically controlled bio-fabrication of anchored 3D crosslinked tissue engineering scaffold and bio-ink for spatially accurate minimally
invasive printing inside of a living patient.

Page 2 of 3
Example #2
Focus Area: Health Science Futures
Title: Mind Meld
Proposed transformation:
Restoration of voluntary muscle movement via minimally invasive untethered
brain motor neuroprosthesis to provide functional independence of impaired
individuals.
How is it done today, and what are the limits of current practice:
Implanted brain-computer interfaces utilizing either penetrating or subdural
arrays have demonstrated high-fidelity device control but require burr hole
craniotomy for implantation.
What is new, and why do you think it will be successful and transformational:
Functional high-fidelity wireless motor cortex communication without
penetrating the skull enables robust untethered digital device control and
greater individual independence.
Evidence Citation:
Oxley, Thomas J, et al. “Motor Neuroprostheses Implanted with
Neurointerventional Surgery Improves Capacity for Activities of Daily Living
Tasks in Severe Paralysis: First in-Human Experience.” Journal of
NeuroInterventional Surgery, vol. 13, no. 2, 2020, pp. 102–108.,
https://doi.org/10.1136/neurintsurg-2020-016862.
Evidence Summary:
Demonstrated minimally invasive fully implanted wireless electrode array to
transmit signals from the motor cortex for control of digital devices in humans
with flaccid upper limb paralysis.

Page 3 of 3
Example #3
Focus Area: Proactive Health
Title: Windows to the Soul
Proposed transformation:
AI systems can perform key healthcare tasks, such as diagnosing disease as
well as or better than humans enabling providers to focus on uniquely human
skills like empathy and big-picture integration.
How is it done today, and what are the limits of current practice:
Current biomarkers of vascular health require invasive blood sampling, blood
pressure, or pulse wave measurement.
What is new, and why do you think it will be successful and transformational:
AI-enabled retinal vasculature scans offer a non-invasive prognostic
biomarker of vascular health with potentially greater community reach to
identify individuals requiring further clinical assessment.
Evidence Citation:
Rudnicka, Alicja Regina, et al. “Artificial Intelligence-Enabled Retinal
Vasculometry for Prediction of Circulatory Mortality, Myocardial Infarction and
Stroke.” British Journal of Ophthalmology, vol. 106, no. 12, 2022, pp. 1722–1729.,
https://doi.org/10.1136/bjo-2022-321842.
Evidence Summary:
An AI algorithm evaluating retinal images delivers 10-year risk scores for
stroke and heart disease equal to one of the most commonly used diagnostic
tools (Framingham Risk Score).
These three examples showcase different innovations within the Health Science Futures focus area:

Put this idea in the following format you see above. And use these 2 citations only: 

Alamo, T., Reina, D. G., Mammarella, M., & Abellán, J. (2020). COVID-19: Open-data resources for monitoring, modeling, and forecasting the epidemic. Electronics, 9(5), 827.
DOI: 10.3390/electronics9050827
URL: https://doi.org/10.3390/electronics9050827

Bragazzi, N. L., Dai, H., Damiani, G., Behzadifar, M., Martini, M., & Wu, J. (2019). How big data and artificial intelligence can help better manage the COVID-19 pandemic. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 17(9), 3176.
DOI: 10.3390/ijerph17093176
URL: https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph17093176

Focus Area: Health Science Futures & Resilient Systems

Title: AI-Enabled Real-Time Disease Surveillance and Response System for Resilient Healthcare

Proposed transformation: Develop an AI-enabled real-time disease surveillance and response system that integrates various data sources, including patient health records, social media, and public health reports, to predict and respond to emerging disease outbreaks quickly and efficiently. The system will use advanced analytics to identify patterns and detect disease outbreaks early, allowing healthcare providers to implement timely and effective interventions to minimize the spread of the disease and prevent pandemics. The system will be designed to be adaptable to various healthcare settings, including hospitals, clinics, and public health agencies.

How is it done today, and what are the limits of current practice: Disease surveillance and outbreak response are primarily carried out through manual data collection and analysis, which is time-consuming, error-prone, and can result in delayed responses to outbreaks.

What is new, and why do you think it will be successful and transformational: The proposed system will leverage emerging technologies, such as AI, machine learning, and natural language processing, to automate disease surveillance and response, enabling healthcare providers to respond more quickly and efficiently to outbreaks. The system will provide real-time insights into emerging disease outbreaks, enabling healthcare providers to take proactive measures to prevent the spread of the disease.

Example #4
Focus Area: Health Science Futures & Resilient Systems
Title: AI-Enabled Real-Time Disease Surveillance and Response System for Resilient Healthcare
Proposed transformation:
Develop an AI-enabled real-time disease surveillance and response system that integrates various data sources, including patient health records, social media, and public health reports, to predict and respond to emerging disease outbreaks quickly and efficiently. The system will use advanced analytics to identify patterns and detect disease outbreaks early, allowing healthcare providers to implement timely and effective interventions to minimize the spread of the disease and prevent pandemics. The system will be designed to be adaptable to various healthcare settings, including hospitals, clinics, and public health agencies.

How is it done today, and what are the limits of current practice:
Disease surveillance and outbreak response are primarily carried out through manual data collection and analysis, which is time-consuming, error-prone, and can result in delayed responses to outbreaks.

What is new, and why do you think it will be successful and transformational:
The proposed system will leverage emerging technologies, such as AI, machine learning, and natural language processing, to automate disease surveillance and response, enabling healthcare providers to respond more quickly and efficiently to outbreaks. The system will provide real-time insights into emerging disease outbreaks, enabling healthcare providers to take proactive measures to prevent the spread of the disease.

Evidence Citation #1:
Alamo, T., Reina, D. G., Mammarella, M., & Abellán, J. (2020). COVID-19: Open-data resources for monitoring, modeling, and forecasting the epidemic. Electronics, 9(5), 827.
DOI: 10.3390/electronics9050827
URL: <https://doi.org/10.3390/electronics9050827>

Evidence Summary #1:
This study highlights the importance of open-data resources for monitoring, modeling, and forecasting the COVID-19 epidemic and suggests that these resources can be utilized to improve disease surveillance and response efforts.

Evidence Citation #2:
Bragazzi, N. L., Dai, H., Damiani, G., Behzadifar, M., Martini, M., & Wu, J. (2019). How big data and artificial intelligence can help better manage the COVID-19 pandemic. International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 17(9), 3176.
DOI: 10.3390/ijerph17093176
URL: <https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph17093176>

Evidence Summary #2:
This article discusses the potential of big data and artificial intelligence in managing the COVID-19 pandemic and emphasizes their role in enhancing disease surveillance, monitoring, and response capabilities.
